SENT.plain: Electroencephalographic recordings were obtained during 13 episodes of transient global amnesia in 13 patients
Eight were entirely normal; none showed seizure discharges or other epileptiform activity

Electroencephalographic recordings were also obtained after 103 episodes of amnesia in 96 patients with transient global amnesia (TGA) alone, five patients who had both TGA and epilepsy independently, and three patients with amnesia related to epilepsy
The majority (60.8%) of waking records were normal during or after episodes of TGA
Mild or moderate and nonfocal abnormalities were found in a minority
Genuine epileptiform activity was observed only among patients who had seizure disorders
Amnestic episodes attributable to seizures were more brief and more apt to be repeated than TGA and usually responded to anticonvulsant drugs
Differentiation of TGA from epilepsy is essential for appropriate management
